reviewText: Operation Flashpoint: Red River is kind of like a mixture of ArmA, MOH and Ghost Recon. You command your fireteam (like GR) except in a more complicated way similar to ArmA (stance, dispersion, noise dicipline etc.) There are ArmA features like bullet drop, the importance of stance when aiming, military jargon that is relevant to the task and some adherence to military tactics. The AI (unlike ArmA) are actually somewhat lifelike, and they behave much like the AI in say MOH BF3/4 and GR. Unfortunately, the environment isn't breakable (like BF3/4), however you can reduce buildings to rubble with high explosives but that is it. Suppressors aren't that useful because of the way the campaign is played (open ground and daylight) but fortunately they do not reduce damage like in some games. The weapons are rather innacurate, almost to the point that they are unusable. The M4A1 carbine is good for distances up to max 20m away (the ACOG magnifies too much). The M249E2 SAW is about the same. The MP5A4 is good for targets up to 10m away. The M14 is best with the Leupold Mk 4 because the ACOG sits too far forward on the weapon and the peripherals interfere. The M107 is useful for any range, but if targets are within 100m, then aim using the graduations above the middle of the crosshair.\n\nIn conclusion, I would recommend it to anyone. It's fun by yourself (the AI are competent) and fun with friends or even strangers (the online community are quite pleasant).

reviewText:
I've seen a lot of people compare this to Arma or Battlefield, and then say this game is rather dissapointing. The game is more like MoH or CoD, in the sense that it isn't openworld, and the missions are very linear. Where it differs from MoH or CoD however is in the gameplay. Unlike you're generic FPS military game, you are not a walking tank that can run through the battlefield taking little to no damage whilst wreaking havoc on your enemies using an array of weapons. In OF you have 4 distinct classes, with different weapon setups, and by playing as the classes you can unlock different weapons to use and more customization options, none of which however are capable of running and gunning through the battelfield due to how easy it is to be killed. Even on normal you can get killed in as few as 2 bullets. Due to this the gameplay is a lot slower paced than other FPS games you may be used too, but it is still very enjoyable. Personally I found it a nice change from the standard FPS games. The story however is rather dissapointing. It's your standard military story where you are in a foreign country trying to restore peace by killing anything that moves, and overall the story is forgettable.

Now one of the major downsides to this game is the need to install Games for Windows Live. Youll need to install the GFWL client seperatly from the windows/xbox site before being able to launch the game, and you will need to sign into an Xbox live account in order to play co-op/multiplayer and to be able to save your progress. It's important to note however, that the multiplayer and co-op is still functional despite GFWL not being supported anymore, which is a good thing since the game is a lot more fun to play with friends as the AI squadmates generally are not very useful.

The graphics have not aged well and even back in 2011 when the game was launched the graphics weren't that great, and the game isn't optimised that well for PC. With that being said though, the game is still a lot of fun to play, and has a lot of gameplay value, especially for its current low cost. I'd give OF:Red River a solid 7/10

PS: The game plays a little smoother with a xbox controller over keyboard and mouse, but is still playable with them if you don't happen to have a controller. Also GFWL may not be getting updated anymore, but it works fine, so people should stop complaining about the game and giving it bad ratings based on this one thing.

It's hard to recomend a game like this. Operation Flashpoint has alaways been closer to a tactical military shooter than an arcade shooter like COD. The game tries to blur the lines between arcade and tactial, but fails to really do so. The commands are awkwardly placed on the CAPS Lock key and use WASD to issue. This means that to issue a command you have to completely stop moving, look at your target, hit an unusual key and than select your command. There's also no way to issue individual commands like in previous games. A common strategy is to place a heavy gunner, LMG, on suppressive fire, a sniper on overwatch and than send one soldier to flank right or left while you flank the other direction. However since you have to command the entire team the best you can do is supprese and you flank or send them one way and you go the other.

Another problem with the game is Staff SGT. Knoxx. I get that he's a Marine and the game is tryingto symbolize a military shooter but I've never heard anyone, Marine or otherwise, with as foul a mouth as him and I'm military. He began to irritate me right off the bat and never got better. It got to the point where everytime he started talking I just muted my TV so I wouldn't have to listen to the gutteral trash the developers think we talk like.

Can I recommend this game? No. No I cannot. However I can recomend Operation Flashpoint Dragon Rising for those of yo looking for a good tactical FPS.

reviewText:
Operation Flashpoint: Red River

Positives:

+ A nice change of scenery from the previous installment in the series, Operation Flashpoint: Red River takes you to the war-torn areas of Tajikistan and beyond. You'll be fighting against terrorist hostiles in the desert, while also dealing with the People's Liberation Army of China.
+ Story wise I would say the game is decent, but it doesn't feature anything out of the ordinary or ground-breaking. It's a pretty standard tale of U.S forces securing key objectives like dams and defending Fall Out Bases.
+ As with the first title, Operation Flashpoint: Red River closely resembles a military simulator, so it's great for gamers who want to play tactically.
+ Graphics are passable, not top notch in any respect, but reasonable.


Negatives:

- The guns just don't seem as fluid as the original game. I can't quite put my finger on it, but something is odd. The weapons just appear to be less exciting and more generic. The feeling you have when firing isn't the same as in Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. I'm not complaining about the realism of the weapons, they just have no charm. In Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising, they were both very fun to use and realistic.
- Squad commands are once again a pain to initiate. Really poorly thought-out system that simply doesn't work as intended in the middle of shooting at enemies. Too time consuming and difficult to do. I finished the game purely by solo killing, with my teammates behind me providing default covering fire.
- The game can start out slow, most of the missions aren't too engaging in terms of gameplay. While the new desert atmosphere is nice, it can also be a bit bland at the same time.
- Game is short at 20 hours, although this isn't the worst length for a First Person Shooter I've come across.
- Voice acting is kinda strange to be honest..just a little.

Overall Score: 6/10

Operation Flashpoint: Red River isn't a bad game. It's just not as good as the Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising. It's shorter, the guns aren't as enjoyable, the environment is fresh and new, but it doesn't have the X factor that Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising retained. In the end, it's a game still worth purchasing, but definitely on sale.

This game takes everything that Dragon Rising was, and improves it immensely.

+Mission flow is highly improved. You fight and feel as part of a platoon in the campaign.
+Campaign is actually very interesting and as a semi-sequel to Dragon Rising, really succeeds at sucking you into the story and the action. It is a MAJOR improvement off of Dragon Rising (Which I can't remember a god damn thing about.)
+Good characters. There is at least one character you will never forget after playing this game, and several other interesting ones with their own distinct personalities that you'll hear plenty of throughout the campaign.
+Combat is fluid and as realistic as this series has ever tried to get. This isn't as realistic as ArmA, and this isn't as Arcadey as battlefield, but that's because this doesn't try to be either. This is a good in-between point of those who can find no joy in either.
+Fireteam Engagements allow for extra gameplay after the campaign
+Player Progression system awards you for doing the best you can on all missions and for completing as many secondary objectives as you possibly can.
+Class Setup module allows you to fully customize the loadout of your entire squad before going into a mission.
+Compared to Dragon Rising, this game features HUGE maps with improved grapihcs that allow for long and intense missions. You really feel like you're fighting in one country rather than several maps" as you fight along a road from one border to another.

reviewText:
Offensively bad semi interactive movie and with a terrible control scheme.

The menu system is barely usable with a mouse. I think it wants you to use a controller:

a) You have to press enter in the menus to accept things, rather than clicking accept or escape or something.
b) To change your loadout in the menus you need to use the mousewheel (?!?!) rather than simply clicking on things. This also isn't stated, so it took a while to figure out.
c) You have to use the keyboard to navigate, rather than the mouse.

The game itself is also based entirely around a controller:
a) If the mouse sensitivity is anything higher than 1/10 then moving the mouse causes the screen to do about 50 360s.
b) Even on 0 or 1 the mouse has insane amounts of mouse acceleration, meaning I could hardly aim in the right direction
c) The FOV is like 50 or something. Which, combined with the super-yawing mouse input, means you'll never be able to see anything
d) The game uses a radial menu for squad commands.... but rather than navigate it using the mouse, you need to use WASD!!!! It's really hurt my brain to try and use that input method to give commands.

The game itself is also a barely interactive shooting gallery. Be prepared to spend 8 unskippable hours in a truck with an angry and degrading NCO, and a few moments in action commanding around your fireteam who can barely walk in the direction you tell them.

It also uses GFWL, which was a pain as I couldn't log in for ages (I had to use a separate 'app password'. GFWL didn't tell me this).

I tried to get a refund I found this game so bad, but I'd forgotten that I bought it yesterday in a humble bundle for $2. The game is so crap that I kind of want a refund on the entire bundle now as it's tainted..

reviewText:
The controls are very poor, and were clearly designed with consoles in mind. For example, looking around in a vehicle using the mouse is difficult as the camera constantly tries to revert to its default position (which makes sense if using an analog stick, but not with a mouse). There is also a substantial amount of mouse acceleration, making aiming extremely awkward and difficult. Menus are clunky - console like - and are meant to be navigated using the arrow keys and enter instead of the mouse.

Graphics-wise, the game is unimpressive, especially for a 2011 game. There is heavy pop-in of vegetation, low quality textures, and excessive amounts of blur.

AI is dumb, especially your teammates which do practically nothing. They only come in handy when you get shot and need healing. The gameplay as actually quite linear, and not nearly as open-ended as it might seem. The large scale of enemy units in many cases can make for some entertaining shootouts, but by the end if actually felt much more like Call of Duty than a military simulator.

reviewText:
It's an even bigger departure from it's simulation namesake, however Red River still holds it's own as a decent squad based tactical shooter. The player retains the role of a USMC Fireteam Leader as they guide their fellow Marines and command them to complete the varied mission objectives thrown at them during the campaign.

Pros:
- Game offers a decent amount of tactical flexibaility with it's command system.
- Players will work alongside seperate AI Fireteams as part of a larger Squad, making the player feel a part of a larger war effort.
- Friendly AI now have their own personality, the voice acting is much less robotic than previous games and the natural banter increases immersion.
-The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. It may be confronting at first but I feel it is a realistic and accurate representation of military banter, adds to the immersion and makes the player feel like they're part of a human squad of soldiers.
- Players can now unlock new weapons and equipment, and customise their loadout prior to each mission.

Cons:
- Missions are more linear than the previous game.
- AI still occasionaly glitch or bug out.
- Lack of Mission Editor (a staple of the series) hinders replayabilty.
- The new voice acting comes with a script full of excessive swearing and less than politically correct comments. I personally have no problem with this as I found it to be an accurate depiction of military banter, but some players may find this uncomfortable.

I can reccomend this game for players looking for a more thought based shooter. While it's not as in depth as it's predecessors or rival series (ArmA) it still requires a little bit of patience and strategy to survive the firefights in this campaign.

reviewText:
Bite Size Review

The Good:
+ Authentic Iraq Shooter Exerpience
+ 1 - 2 shots and enemies go down
+ Weapons Feel Powerful
+ First Person Story Telling
+ Squad Command
+ Realistic Objectives (Not Explosions everywhere - just clearing houses etc.)

The Bad:
- Games for Windows Live is Dead (Can't save, can't play online)
- 1 - 2 shots and you go down
- No leaning option that I could find
- Squad Command is requires holding down capslock?
- Graphics and level design show their age here

The Verdict:

This is an older game when it comes to the first person shooter genre. All things considered though I wouldn't mind this game and may actually enjoy it since it does have some good qualities.

However the fact that it requires the now dead platform Games for Windows Live means it features are extremely limited now and kind of broken.

If you are at all interested in this type of game - realistic damage and maps to shoot in - go buy Arma 3. It's seems better in ever way.
